Definition {#definition .unnumbered}
==========

Let $f$ be a function from ${\mathbb{R}}$ to ${\mathbb{R}}$. If
$f(-x)=f(x)$ for all $x\in {\mathbb{R}}$, then $f$ is an *even
function*. Similarly, if $f(-x)=-f(x)$ for all $x\in {\mathbb{R}}$, then
$f$ is an *odd function*.

Although this entry is mainly concerned with functions
${\mathbb{R}}\to{\mathbb{R}}$, the definition can be generalized to
other types of function.

Notes {#notes .unnumbered}
=====

A real function is even if and only if it is symmetric about the
$y$-axis. It is odd if and only if symmetric about the origin.

Examples {#examples .unnumbered}
========

1.  The function $f(x)=x$ is odd.

2.  The function $f(x)=|x|$ is even.

3.  The sine and cosine functions are odd and even, respectively.

Properties {#properties .unnumbered}
==========

1.  The only function that is both even and odd is the function defined
    by $f(x)=0$ for all real $x$.

2.  A sum of even functions is even, and a sum of odd functions is odd.
    In fact, the even functions form a real vector space, as do the odd
    functions.

3.  Every real function can be expressed in a unique way as the sum of
    an odd function and an even function.

4.  From the above it follows that the vector space of real functions is
    the direct sum of the vector space of even functions and the vector
    space of odd functions. See the entry .)

5.  Let $f\colon\mathbb{R}\to \mathbb{R}$ be a differentiable function.

    1.  If $f$ is an even function, then the derivative $f'$ is an odd
        function.

    2.  If $f$ is an odd function, then the derivative $f'$ is an even
        function.

    (For a proof, see the entry .)

6.  Let $f\colon{\mathbb{R}}\to {\mathbb{R}}$ be a smooth function. Then
    there exist smooth functions $g,h\colon{\mathbb{R}}\to{\mathbb{R}}$
    such that $$f(x) = g(x^2)+ xh(x^2)$$ for all $x\in {\mathbb{R}}$.
    Thus, if $f$ is even, we have $f(x)=g(x^2)$, and if $f$ is odd, we
    have $f(x)=xh(x^2)$. ([@hormander], Exercise 1.2)

7.  The Fourier transform of a real even function is purely real and
    even. The Fourier transform of a real odd function is purely
    imaginary and odd.

[9]{} L. Hörmander, *The Analysis of Linear Partial Differential
Operators I, (Distribution theory and Fourier Analysis)*, 2nd ed,
Springer-Verlag, 1990.
